This principle together with the observation that legal rights may not cover all coercive practices entails that legal rights alone do not ensure freedom.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person has legal rights but is subject to social coercion, such as peer pressure or cultural norms, that restrict their freedom. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not. If we say they are free, then we ignore the impact of social coercion. If we say they are not free, then legal rights alone are insufficient for freedom.}

36800b29-90cd-4b42-9ad7-e54513d10217.summary: Is the concept of freedom too complex to be captured by legal rights alone?
36800b29-90cd-4b42-9ad7-e54513d10217.content: {It is implausible that the concept of freedom can be fully captured by legal rights alone, as freedom is a multifaceted concept involving various dimensions such as moral, social, and psychological aspects.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has legal rights but is psychologically manipulated to act against their will. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free.}

ca00702d-06f5-4453-a98c-8ef69d413ef9.summary: Can legal rights ensure freedom in the absence of social equality?
ca00702d-06f5-4453-a98c-8ef69d413ef9.content: {There is a plausible principle that social equality is necessary for true freedom, as significant social inequalities can undermine the ability to exercise legal rights. This principle together with the observation that legal rights can exist in highly unequal societies entails that legal rights alone do not ensure freedom.}, {Suppose we have a case in which a person has legal rights but lives in a society with extreme social inequality that limits their opportunities. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free or that they are not. If we say they are free, then we ignore the impact of social inequality. If we say they are not free, then legal rights alone are insufficient for freedom.}

14a9e50e-fab8-4ebf-b028-0d7c00efd8ce.summary: Do legal rights guarantee freedom if they are subject to arbitrary change?
14a9e50e-fab8-4ebf-b028-0d7c00efd8ce.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has legal rights that are subject to arbitrary change by those in power. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free, as their rights are unstable and unreliable.}, {It is implausible that legal rights can guarantee freedom if they are subject to arbitrary change, as this undermines the security and predictability necessary for true liberty.}

367304db-daf1-4800-a795-e061453e7dca.summary: Does freedom require absolute equality in all aspects?
367304db-daf1-4800-a795-e061453e7dca.content: {It is implausible that freedom requires absolute equality in all aspects of life.}, {Consider a scenario where two individuals have equal rights and opportunities but different personal choices lead to different outcomes. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that freedom is present despite the inequality in outcomes.}

cb2433d9-f9df-4120-be08-d50a1567f456.summary: Can freedom exist without equal access to all resources?
cb2433d9-f9df-4120-be08-d50a1567f456.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom can exist even when individuals do not have equal access to all resources. This principle together with the observation that individuals can exercise freedom through personal choices and agency entails that freedom does not necessarily require equal access to all resources.}

81d161c4-d8d9-40e3-a8e0-6482f8dae495.summary: Is equality of opportunity sufficient for freedom?
81d161c4-d8d9-40e3-a8e0-6482f8dae495.content: {Suppose we have a case in which individuals have equal opportunities but face systemic barriers that affect their ability to utilize these opportunities. Intuitively, we either have to say that freedom is compromised or that it is not. If we say freedom is compromised, then equality of opportunity alone is insufficient for freedom. If we say freedom is not compromised, then we must accept that freedom can exist without full equality of opportunity.}

a4458658-7b37-499d-a59f-e84fca1ae286.summary: Does treating individuals equally always result in freedom?
a4458658-7b37-499d-a59f-e84fca1ae286.content: {Consider a scenario where individuals are treated equally under the law but face discrimination in practice. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that freedom is not fully realized despite formal equality.}

1616c889-a69a-4e9c-9803-f730abdf9d87.summary: Can freedom be present with unequal rights?
1616c889-a69a-4e9c-9803-f730abdf9d87.content: {It is implausible that freedom can be present when individuals have unequal rights.}, {A case in which some individuals have more rights than others is not a case in which freedom is fully realized.}

b917673e-065a-431d-8ef9-dc86b19016a9.summary: Is equal access to resources necessary for liberty?
b917673e-065a-431d-8ef9-dc86b19016a9.content: {There is a plausible principle that liberty involves the ability to make choices without coercion. This principle together with the observation that individuals can have liberty even with unequal access to resources entails that equal access to resources is not necessary for liberty.}

861a8af1-bb31-4e1d-a4d4-c2b476d73508.content: {Consider a scenario where individuals have equal rights and opportunities but are subject to oppressive laws. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that freedom is not guaranteed by equality alone.}

8f457b15-9cd8-4abf-82a9-c3b75e3a1bf0.summary: Can freedom exist in a society with unequal opportunities?
8f457b15-9cd8-4abf-82a9-c3b75e3a1bf0.content: {Suppose we have a case in which individuals have unequal opportunities due to factors beyond their control, such as socioeconomic status. Intuitively, we either have to say that freedom is absent or that it is present. If we say freedom is absent, then unequal opportunities negate freedom. If we say freedom is present, then freedom can exist despite unequal opportunities.}

5765872c-f23f-4fd5-a7d2-4fb32a2ae8f0.summary: Is equal treatment sufficient for liberty?
5765872c-f23f-4fd5-a7d2-4fb32a2ae8f0.content: {It is implausible that equal treatment alone is sufficient for liberty.}, {A case in which individuals are treated equally but lack the ability to make meaningful choices is not a case in which liberty is fully realized.}

fa022af0-48e6-448e-8b71-81519952ff3a.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves the ability to pursue one's own goals. This principle together with the observation that individuals can achieve different outcomes based on personal choices entails that freedom does not require equal outcomes.}

89e9d06c-e70b-4f25-8371-822ade9008d3.summary: Can freedom exist without the possibility of choice?
89e9d06c-e70b-4f25-8371-822ade9008d3.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the ability to choose between alternatives. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom cannot exist if there are no alternatives to choose from.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but has no alternatives to choose from. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual is not free.}

c603f276-6e1f-4664-a4fd-2979868f95fd.summary: Does the absence of necessity guarantee meaningful freedom?
c603f276-6e1f-4664-a4fd-2979868f95fd.content: {Suppose we have a case in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but is still unable to pursue their desires due to external constraints. Intuitively, we either have to say that the individual is free or that they are not free. If we say the individual is free, then freedom seems trivial. If we say the individual is not free, then absence of necessity is not sufficient for freedom.}

0937164d-1408-4fd4-bcef-e71c7d7e10d6.summary: Is freedom compatible with internal constraints?
0937164d-1408-4fd4-bcef-e71c7d7e10d6.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by external circumstances but is driven by internal compulsions, such as addiction. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual is not free.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not only the absence of external necessity but also the absence of internal constraints. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that internal constraints can undermine freedom.}

84c55165-13c2-44f7-aeb5-e4f83d65b6cf.summary: Can freedom be defined without reference to moral or ethical considerations?
84c55165-13c2-44f7-aeb5-e4f83d65b6cf.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom is not merely a physical or circumstantial condition but also involves moral or ethical dimensions. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom cannot be fully understood without considering moral or ethical factors.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but acts immorally. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual may not be truly free in a moral sense.}

385fdb11-cbf0-4bd9-ad1a-9e7fb018786c.summary: Does the absence of necessity account for social and political dimensions of freedom?
385fdb11-cbf0-4bd9-ad1a-9e7fb018786c.content: {Suppose we have a case in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but lives in a society with oppressive laws. Intuitively, we either have to say that the individual is free or that they are not free. If we say the individual is free, then freedom seems disconnected from social and political realities. If we say the individual is not free, then absence of necessity is not sufficient for freedom.}

1964558e-c9bc-40ee-a177-d426fe8d8e58.summary: Is freedom as absence of necessity too individualistic?
1964558e-c9bc-40ee-a177-d426fe8d8e58.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves not only individual conditions but also relational and communal aspects. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom cannot be fully understood in purely individualistic terms.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but is isolated from community and relationships. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual lacks a certain kind of freedom.}

e1b546b5-8b12-41b7-b9e0-773eb70ca35a.summary: Can freedom exist in deterministic systems?
e1b546b5-8b12-41b7-b9e0-773eb70ca35a.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the possibility of acting otherwise. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom cannot exist in a deterministic system where actions are predetermined.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual's actions are determined by prior states of the world, yet they are not compelled by immediate circumstances. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual is not free.}

ff16a075-22b8-4190-851f-9c659b81327c.summary: Does the absence of necessity address the role of power in freedom?
ff16a075-22b8-4190-851f-9c659b81327c.content: {Suppose we have a case in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but is subject to the power and influence of others. Intuitively, we either have to say that the individual is free or that they are not free. If we say the individual is free, then freedom seems to ignore the dynamics of power. If we say the individual is not free, then absence of necessity is not sufficient for freedom.}

b6784e24-ac15-46e9-ad09-d3e0d33c5d10.summary: Is freedom as absence of necessity compatible with responsibility?
b6784e24-ac15-46e9-ad09-d3e0d33c5d10.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom involves the capacity for responsibility and accountability. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom must include the ability to be responsible for one's actions.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but cannot be held accountable for their actions. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual is not truly free.}

8cfd72fc-28f4-4c07-b09a-b902e51c889d.summary: Does the absence of necessity adequately capture the concept of autonomy?
8cfd72fc-28f4-4c07-b09a-b902e51c889d.content: {There is a plausible principle that autonomy involves self-governance and the ability to make one's own decisions. This principle together with the idea that freedom is the absence of necessity entails that freedom must include the capacity for autonomous decision-making.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual is not compelled by circumstances but lacks the ability to make independent choices. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual is not autonomous.}

71372771-baf0-4e1e-b622-77a3925d5c42.summary: Can freedom exist without external constraints?
71372771-baf0-4e1e-b622-77a3925d5c42.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual is locked in a room but is unaware of this fact and desires to stay in the room. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual lacks freedom despite determining their own path.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the absence of external constraints. This principle together with the scenario entails that self-determination alone is insufficient for freedom.}

7263402a-7012-4063-bdb7-38f76e9ea034.summary: Is self-determination sufficient for true freedom?
7263402a-7012-4063-bdb7-38f76e9ea034.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is manipulated into wanting a specific life path through subliminal messaging. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free because they determine their own path or that they are not free because their choices are manipulated. If we say the person is free, then self-determination is sufficient for freedom. If we say the person is not free, then self-determination is not sufficient for true freedom.}

7da220ee-203b-4023-a29f-561535e15a7b.summary: Does liberty require the ability to change one's goals?
7da220ee-203b-4023-a29f-561535e15a7b.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual can pursue their current goals but lacks the ability to change these goals due to external pressures. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that liberty is compromised.}, {There is a plausible principle that liberty requires not only the pursuit of current goals but also the ability to revise them. This principle together with the scenario entails that mere pursuit of goals is insufficient for liberty.}

fd7a4e9b-acda-4641-952e-2a25de88aa5f.summary: Can self-determination occur without knowledge of options?
fd7a4e9b-acda-4641-952e-2a25de88aa5f.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is unaware of alternative life paths due to lack of information. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is self-determined because they make choices or that they are not self-determined because they lack knowledge of options. If we say the person is self-determined, then knowledge of options is not necessary. If we say the person is not self-determined, then knowledge of options is necessary for self-determination.}

068e582d-b3d9-43a6-a7bf-405b891d39ea.content: {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the ability to do otherwise. This principle together with the idea that determinism implies a single possible future entails that freedom is incompatible with determinism.}, {Consider a scenario in which every action is determined by prior events and laws of nature. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that individuals lack freedom.}

e3d31830-e443-4b8f-8f3a-021d5aa78eef.summary: Does pursuing goals ensure liberty if goals are externally imposed?
e3d31830-e443-4b8f-8f3a-021d5aa78eef.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual can pursue their goals, but these goals are imposed by an authoritarian regime. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that liberty is absent.}, {There is a plausible principle that liberty requires the ability to pursue self-chosen goals. This principle together with the scenario entails that pursuing externally imposed goals does not ensure liberty.}

adcebb48-28ac-4ba4-a43d-9f9abda1a93d.summary: Can self-determination exist in a coercive environment?
adcebb48-28ac-4ba4-a43d-9f9abda1a93d.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person makes choices about their life direction under threat of harm. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is self-determined because they make choices or that they are not self-determined because of coercion. If we say the person is self-determined, then coercion is compatible with self-determination. If we say the person is not self-determined, then coercion undermines self-determination.}

52cce5c9-3ca5-4dbf-8c71-2b3f05e14249.summary: Is freedom meaningful without the capacity for critical reflection?
52cce5c9-3ca5-4dbf-8c71-2b3f05e14249.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual can determine their own path but lacks the capacity for critical reflection on their choices. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that freedom is diminished.}, {There is a plausible principle that freedom requires the capacity for critical reflection. This principle together with the scenario entails that self-determination without reflection is insufficient for meaningful freedom.}

d9c8e3e3-dc13-4cb4-b30d-455bcd556340.summary: Does liberty require equality of opportunity?
d9c8e3e3-dc13-4cb4-b30d-455bcd556340.content: {There is a plausible principle that liberty requires equality of opportunity. This principle together with the observation that social and economic inequalities limit opportunities entails that liberty is compromised in unequal societies.}, {Consider a scenario in which individuals can pursue their goals but face unequal opportunities due to systemic discrimination. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that liberty is not fully realized.}

eaa68729-a675-4ed0-ace8-d71461aa136e.summary: Can freedom be realized in the absence of autonomy?
eaa68729-a675-4ed0-ace8-d71461aa136e.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person follows a predetermined life script without exercising autonomy. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is free because they follow a path or that they are not free because they lack autonomy. If we say the person is free, then autonomy is not necessary for freedom. If we say the person is not free, then autonomy is necessary for freedom.}

34c1e192-2a71-416d-bb01-7daf618a664d.summary: Does empowerment necessarily lead to freedom?
34c1e192-2a71-416d-bb01-7daf618a664d.content: {There is a plausible principle that having the ability and resources to make choices does not necessarily lead to freedom. This principle together with the idea that external constraints can still limit freedom entails that empowerment alone is insufficient for true freedom.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has the resources and ability to make choices but is under constant surveillance. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person is not truly free.}

51ee37a1-e318-46ee-a96f-cbb2944642cd.summary: Can empowerment exist without genuine choice?
51ee37a1-e318-46ee-a96f-cbb2944642cd.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has the resources to make choices but all options are equally undesirable. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person is empowered or that they are not. If we say the person is empowered, then empowerment does not require genuine choice. If we say the person is not empowered, then empowerment requires more than just resources.}, {It is implausible that empowerment can exist without genuine choice, as empowerment implies meaningful options.}

f7c135b7-b66f-4ad2-9abf-c06b46d5d22a.summary: Is empowerment always beneficial for liberty?
f7c135b7-b66f-4ad2-9abf-c06b46d5d22a.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is empowered with resources and abilities but uses them to harm themselves or others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that empowerment is not beneficial for liberty.}, {There is a plausible principle that empowerment should lead to positive outcomes for it to be considered beneficial. This principle together with the potential for negative use of empowerment entails that empowerment is not always beneficial for liberty.}

dbc1536b-8c1d-487b-8427-65330efd39ad.summary: Can empowerment be a source of oppression?
dbc1536b-8c1d-487b-8427-65330efd39ad.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a group is empowered with resources and abilities but uses them to oppress another group. Intuitively, we either have to say that empowerment is a source of oppression or that it is not. If we say empowerment is a source of oppression, then empowerment can be negative. If we say it is not, then empowerment must be inherently positive.}, {It is implausible that empowerment is inherently positive, as it can be used to oppress others.}

eb376bcd-e40f-4e4f-8eae-03d31ac8e7f6.summary: Does empowerment guarantee the power to influence one's life?
eb376bcd-e40f-4e4f-8eae-03d31ac8e7f6.content: {There is a plausible principle that having resources and abilities does not guarantee the power to influence one's life. This principle together with the existence of external factors that can negate personal influence entails that empowerment does not guarantee liberty.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person has resources and abilities but is subject to unpredictable external forces. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person lacks true power to influence their life.}

3733bed3-b2e3-4f7c-a21f-5bd1d22abb81.summary: Is empowerment sufficient for achieving liberty?
3733bed3-b2e3-4f7c-a21f-5bd1d22abb81.content: {It is implausible that empowerment alone is sufficient for achieving liberty, as liberty requires more than just resources and abilities.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person is empowered with resources and abilities but lives in a society with restrictive laws. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person does not have liberty.}

e23f5fd6-4beb-4e1b-8625-04b63c3dde20.summary: Can empowerment be a burden rather than a benefit?
e23f5fd6-4beb-4e1b-8625-04b63c3dde20.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is empowered with numerous choices, leading to decision paralysis. Intuitively, we either have to say that empowerment is a burden or that it is not. If we say it is a burden, then empowerment can be negative. If we say it is not, then empowerment must always be positive.}, {It is implausible that empowerment is always positive, as it can lead to overwhelming choices and stress.}

dc61c88a-ba37-4382-b928-4c51c5b7c911.content: {There is a plausible principle that empowerment requires recognition and validation from others. This principle together with the idea that empowerment is a social construct entails that empowerment is not solely an individual state.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person believes they are empowered but is not recognized as such by society. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's empowerment is incomplete.}

01168659-4f91-44ab-89cd-db9af2a11e53.summary: Is empowerment inherently linked to moral responsibility?
01168659-4f91-44ab-89cd-db9af2a11e53.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is empowered with resources and abilities but uses them irresponsibly. Intuitively, we either have to say that empowerment is linked to moral responsibility or that it is not. If we say it is linked, then empowerment carries moral weight. If we say it is not, then empowerment is morally neutral.}, {It is implausible that empowerment is morally neutral, as it involves the capacity to affect others.}

a015dd82-7bbc-4e8a-ae2e-a04052f2a300.summary: Can empowerment exist in isolation from social structures?
a015dd82-7bbc-4e8a-ae2e-a04052f2a300.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is isolated from society but has resources and abilities. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's empowerment is limited.}, {There is a plausible principle that empowerment is influenced by social structures. This principle together with the interconnectedness of individuals in society entails that empowerment cannot exist in isolation.}

8b09ca8d-bff9-4d63-b859-d95f8a377518.summary: Can freedom exist if fear is irrational?
8b09ca8d-bff9-4d63-b859-d95f8a377518.content: {Fear can be irrational and not based on actual potential harm or consequences.}, {If freedom is defined as the absence of fear, then irrational fears would imply a lack of freedom even when no real threat exists.}, {It is implausible that freedom should be contingent on the absence of irrational fears.}

87c17c47-12f7-465c-b807-0be402cd6d36.summary: Does freedom require complete absence of fear?
87c17c47-12f7-465c-b807-0be402cd6d36.content: {It is implausible that individuals can ever be completely free of fear.}, {If freedom requires the complete absence of fear, then it is unattainable for most individuals.}, {An unattainable concept of freedom is not practically useful or meaningful.}

8692892c-e9bb-473b-88f6-3ff65d0ad65d.summary: Can freedom exist in the presence of justified fear?
8692892c-e9bb-473b-88f6-3ff65d0ad65d.content: {Consider a scenario where a person is justifiably afraid of a real and present danger.}, {In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person can still be free in other aspects of their life.}, {If freedom is defined as the absence of fear, then justified fear would imply a lack of freedom, which seems counterintuitive.}

1f33318b-4130-49e9-95a3-57fddd18da80.summary: Is freedom compatible with fear of social disapproval?
1f33318b-4130-49e9-95a3-57fddd18da80.content: {Fear of social disapproval can prevent individuals from acting freely.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then fear of social disapproval would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should be contingent on the absence of fear of social disapproval, as this is a common and often unavoidable aspect of social life.}

03176eb6-62ad-4a1d-a4b0-f4878b174148.summary: Does freedom require absence of fear in all contexts?
03176eb6-62ad-4a1d-a4b0-f4878b174148.content: {Consider a scenario where a person is afraid in one context but not in another.}, {In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person can be free in the context where they are not afraid.}, {If freedom is defined as the absence of fear, then fear in any context would imply a lack of freedom, which seems overly restrictive.}

c1ebd26e-8e66-4e1b-b57f-de322224fdb0.summary: Can freedom coexist with fear of failure?
c1ebd26e-8e66-4e1b-b57f-de322224fdb0.content: {Fear of failure can motivate individuals to strive for success.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then fear of failure would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should exclude the motivational aspects of fear, such as fear of failure.}

2f41ffd5-4c7b-4e36-b14a-08c27a52877b.summary: Is freedom possible in the presence of existential fear?
2f41ffd5-4c7b-4e36-b14a-08c27a52877b.content: {Existential fear, such as fear of death, is a common human experience.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then existential fear would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should be contingent on the absence of existential fear, as this is a fundamental aspect of human existence.}

ccadc94f-33a1-46bc-9503-43106a3ceff7.summary: Does freedom require absence of fear of authority?
ccadc94f-33a1-46bc-9503-43106a3ceff7.content: {Fear of authority can prevent individuals from acting against unjust systems.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then fear of authority would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should be contingent on the absence of fear of authority, as this fear can be a rational response to oppressive systems.}

bbd1dd94-3d0d-4958-baa1-7fac8df13d57.summary: Can freedom exist with fear of the unknown?
bbd1dd94-3d0d-4958-baa1-7fac8df13d57.content: {Fear of the unknown is a natural human response to uncertainty.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then fear of the unknown would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should be contingent on the absence of fear of the unknown, as this is an inherent part of human cognition.}

cef22cef-05c4-4534-b4a9-b36ecd15c2a2.summary: Is freedom possible with fear of loss?
cef22cef-05c4-4534-b4a9-b36ecd15c2a2.content: {Fear of loss can prevent individuals from taking risks.}, {If freedom is the absence of fear, then fear of loss would imply a lack of freedom.}, {It is implausible that freedom should exclude the protective aspects of fear, such as fear of loss.}

bc837372-7bb9-4c49-9fc8-3553a9ff1915.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity of others to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the arbitrary will of others}

d0453f4e-1117-489d-9582-01d37358d0d4.content: {Freedom is the ability to realize one's true self}, {Self-realization involves acting in accordance with one's authentic desires and values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can pursue their genuine goals and aspirations}

7fb40948-8fd7-43f9-87d7-5232f10eb0be.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-governance}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own reasoning and values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can make choices independently of external control}

6cb5237f-5474-44e7-b56f-c2ce2d0d2756.content: {Freedom is the absence of constraints on action}, {Constraints can be external or internal, including self-imposed ones}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals face no barriers to pursuing their chosen actions}

b2533366-d56e-42d3-973e-1a4ba5381d98.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable outcomes}, {Capabilities are the real opportunities to accomplish what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the means to pursue their valued goals}

af97bde6-c9bd-46cf-b342-a64a85c0df42.summary: Distinguishing between external and internal constraints
af97bde6-c9bd-46cf-b342-a64a85c0df42.content: {There is a distinction between external interference and internal constraints}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with external interference, not internal constraints}, {Self-imposed constraints do not count as interference from others}, {The presence of self-imposed constraints does not affect the absence of external interference}

5fe6e931-3e20-4a96-affa-c5ab094cf20d.summary: Rejecting the intuition that self-imposed constraints limit freedom
5fe6e931-3e20-4a96-affa-c5ab094cf20d.content: {It is mistaken to think that self-imposed constraints limit freedom in the sense of non-interference}, {Freedom as non-interference is only about the absence of external obstacles}, {Self-imposed constraints are a result of personal choice and do not constitute interference}

f7c3f7e7-8a85-4665-a5f0-dd6fc784ac49.summary: Supplementing with the assumption of autonomy
f7c3f7e7-8a85-4665-a5f0-dd6fc784ac49.content: {Autonomy involves self-governance and the ability to set one's own constraints}, {Freedom as non-interference can coexist with autonomy}, {Self-imposed constraints are expressions of autonomy, not limitations on freedom}, {The presence of self-imposed constraints does not negate the absence of external interference}

81c6de0c-05da-45e2-bde4-e2eae21b8d76.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the arbitrary will of others}

46fda49d-6efb-4628-8c1b-bea09b17b18b.content: {Freedom is the absence of constraints on action}, {Constraints can be physical, social, or psychological}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals face no constraints on their actions}

e60818de-4ec6-4219-8a5f-564beb8720ea.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable outcomes}, {Capabilities are the real opportunities to accomplish what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to pursue their goals}

8542da07-8b8c-4fe7-ae1a-ccb0622e3bae.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-determination}, {Autonomy involves making choices based on one's own values and reasons}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can govern themselves according to their own principles}

28b86eee-a840-48e0-ae70-8f27dae075a4.content: {Freedom is the absence of subjugation to the will of others}, {Subjugation involves being subject to the control or authority of others}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are not under the control of others}

36ec461b-bf23-45da-9de8-95adcbcc2694.summary: Distinguishing between intentional and unintentional interference
36ec461b-bf23-45da-9de8-95adcbcc2694.content: {There is a distinction between intentional and unintentional interference}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with intentional interference by others}, {Unintentional actions, such as accidents or natural events, do not constitute interference in the relevant sense}, {The concept of interference in this theory requires intentionality to be relevant to freedom}

a1827e68-fed0-4414-8337-7c416e7769ed.summary: Rejecting the claim that unintentional actions constitute interference
a1827e68-fed0-4414-8337-7c416e7769ed.content: {It is false that unintentional actions, such as accidents or natural events, constitute interference}, {Interference, as defined in the theory, involves intentional prevention of actions}, {Unintentional actions do not meet the criteria for interference as they lack intentionality}

8351fc7d-db13-44c9-b721-99e78f97ea4b.summary: Supplementing with a focus on social and political contexts
8351fc7d-db13-44c9-b721-99e78f97ea4b.content: {The theory can be supplemented by focusing on social and political contexts where intentionality is relevant}, {In social and political contexts, interference typically involves intentional actions by agents}, {Unintentional actions are not relevant to the concept of interference in these contexts}

4af269b7-1284-44c2-99ae-a49048bf1873.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the arbitrary power of others}

a3380211-e1c9-49b3-a1c6-1e6452e8b641.content: {Freedom is the ability to determine one's own actions}, {Self-determination involves making choices based on one's own values and desires}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can pursue their own goals without external constraints}

e9ceac74-872d-4684-8029-8ba6000475b6.content: {Freedom is the capacity for autonomous decision-making}, {Autonomy involves acting according to one's own reasoned principles}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can govern themselves according to their own rational deliberations}

e424e672-b553-4b90-83e2-138341d893e2.summary: Freedom as Non-Domination with Structural Considerations
e424e672-b553-4b90-83e2-138341d893e2.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the arbitrary power of others and social structures do not inherently limit actions}

1ab20957-da07-4b45-9cf8-4ebf5240b47e.content: {Freedom is the empowerment to act effectively}, {Empowerment involves having the resources and opportunities to pursue one's goals}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the means to achieve their aims without undue constraints}

2d7b090c-5ae4-4ade-8670-1b9c79814700.content: {Freedom is the capability to achieve valuable functionings}, {Capabilities involve having the real opportunities to do and be what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to pursue their well-being}

61261a47-b4a6-40bd-847a-fd714d63d73b.content: {Freedom is the presence of control over one's own life}, {Positive liberty involves having the power and resources to fulfill one's potential}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the ability to shape their own destinies}

86b54b08-464e-4955-a1fa-b4d60c51b180.summary: Freedom as Non-Interference with Structural Awareness
86b54b08-464e-4955-a1fa-b4d60c51b180.content: {Freedom is the absence of interference from others}, {Interference involves the intentional prevention of actions}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can act without obstruction from others and social structures do not inherently limit actions}

52aefa15-82bc-4ce6-a062-a6a9c8c51032.summary: Distinguishing between direct and structural interference
52aefa15-82bc-4ce6-a062-a6a9c8c51032.content: {There is a distinction between direct interference and structural limitations}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with direct interference by individuals, not structural limitations}, {Social structures do not constitute direct interference as they are not intentional acts by individuals}, {Liberty is about minimizing intentional prevention of actions by others, not about eliminating all structural limitations}

a1e496f5-d172-415d-94ae-2b6deb3d31f0.summary: Rejecting the claim that social structures inherently limit liberty
a1e496f5-d172-415d-94ae-2b6deb3d31f0.content: {It is false that social structures inherently limit liberty in the sense relevant to non-interference}, {Social structures can facilitate liberty by providing a framework within which individuals can act freely}, {The presence of laws and norms does not necessarily prevent actions but can guide and enable them}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can act without intentional obstruction, not when all social structures are absent}

50630261-ac70-4f81-be10-6a212d67f88e.summary: Supplementing with the assumption of positive liberty
50630261-ac70-4f81-be10-6a212d67f88e.content: {Positive liberty involves the capacity to act upon one's free will, not just the absence of interference}, {Social structures can enhance positive liberty by providing resources and opportunities}, {The objection loses its force if we assume that liberty includes both non-interference and the capacity to act}, {Maximizing liberty involves balancing non-interference with the enhancement of positive capacities}

825384f2-058a-48da-a0be-2f3f9a1f68f8.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the threat of arbitrary interference}

2b364d32-9c53-498d-a6bb-6db0fe611858.content: {Freedom involves the development of one's capacities}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can pursue self-realization}, {Self-realization requires the presence of opportunities and resources}

4987ea10-188d-4130-b1c0-7c24a5ed9afc.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable functionings}, {Valuable functionings are states of being and doing that individuals have reason to value}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capability to achieve these functionings}

aa83cf52-cb39-4f5e-8133-fe2d4c6e8dda.content: {Freedom involves having the power to make choices}, {Empowerment requires access to resources and information}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to make informed choices}

518aa0af-7ad8-4216-bb08-f60957ba4a69.content: {Freedom is the ability to be one's own master}, {Positive liberty involves self-determination and self-mastery}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can govern themselves according to their own values}

017250a8-f4fe-418c-a237-8487b4c23a91.content: {Freedom involves acting according to reason}, {Rational autonomy requires the ability to make informed and rational choices}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals act in accordance with their rational will}

b02c0bee-6980-4eb2-909d-ecbd0b99ec82.content: {Freedom is the absence of constraints on action}, {Constraints can be physical, social, or psychological}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals face no constraints on their actions}

283bed78-bf3b-49a3-84fb-4e99bf1156cc.content: {Freedom involves having a range of opportunities}, {Opportunities require the presence of multiple options}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have access to diverse opportunities}

5e263a83-843f-49f3-9df0-bf34795e7342.content: {Freedom involves living authentically}, {Authenticity requires alignment between one's actions and true self}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can express their true selves}

a2a92140-0f00-41ee-a270-3dd8cb36cfa0.content: {Freedom involves participation in decision-making}, {Participatory autonomy requires involvement in collective decisions}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can participate in shaping the rules that govern them}

556a0ca9-4a49-4423-a75a-322ac7b9b394.content: {There is a distinction between freedom and autonomy}, {Freedom as non-interference is a theory about the absence of external constraints}, {Autonomy involves additional elements such as the presence of options and informed decision-making}, {The objection confuses the concept of freedom with the broader concept of autonomy}

bb3ec228-d0af-4289-a35f-aeee151168be.summary: Rejecting the necessity of options for freedom
bb3ec228-d0af-4289-a35f-aeee151168be.content: {It is false that meaningful autonomy requires the presence of options}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with the absence of intentional prevention, not the availability of options}, {The presence of options is not necessary for freedom if no one is actively preventing action}

c3d7dffd-bd99-4225-8e1d-301467fe3b98.summary: Supplementing with a focus on internal conditions
c3d7dffd-bd99-4225-8e1d-301467fe3b98.content: {Freedom as non-interference can be supplemented with a focus on internal conditions for autonomy}, {Internal conditions such as the ability to make informed choices can be considered separately from external interference}, {The absence of interference remains a necessary condition for freedom, while internal conditions address autonomy}

639fcefb-ee45-4848-89dd-f7f288366154.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the arbitrary will of others}

3b34d1b3-517f-4744-963c-7bdfc40d0ffc.content: {Freedom is the absence of constraints on action}, {Constraints can be physical, legal, or social}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals face no constraints on their actions}

3891df81-94b7-4b77-94c9-5bc6319b78c0.content: {Freedom is the ability to make one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-determination}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can govern themselves without external control}

d250cef0-f724-4edb-b11c-60abe6bc5e41.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable outcomes}, {Capabilities are the real opportunities to accomplish what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to achieve their goals}

f0383de7-f075-461a-928a-1f843e34096b.content: {Freedom is the empowerment to pursue one's interests}, {Empowerment involves having the resources and opportunities to act}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to pursue their interests}

a3f0f589-9e7f-42c8-9925-69ea4728def1.content: {There is a distinction between direct interference and indirect interference}, {Freedom as non-interference is primarily concerned with direct interference}, {Indirect actions like manipulation or coercion do not constitute direct interference}, {The theory focuses on the absence of direct prevention of actions, not on indirect influences}

dc9bf702-46d3-49cc-8830-bb9cae88d592.content: {It is false that indirect actions like manipulation or coercion constitute interference}, {Interference requires the intentional prevention of actions, which indirect actions do not achieve}, {The influence of manipulation or coercion does not equate to the prevention of actions}

03b5ca87-71eb-4ead-917f-3bc5b0a4e8d5.summary: Supplementing with a focus on intentionality
03b5ca87-71eb-4ead-917f-3bc5b0a4e8d5.content: {Interference involves intentional actions aimed at preventing specific actions}, {Indirect actions like manipulation or coercion lack the direct intentionality required for interference}, {The theory can accommodate indirect influences by emphasizing the role of intentionality in defining interference}

d87da129-d987-4d07-aaa8-951abc6f0724.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the threat of arbitrary interference}

6ea93c24-e125-4dc8-8992-20e358d008b8.content: {Freedom is the ability to realize one's true self}, {Self-realization involves acting in accordance with one's rational nature}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can pursue their rational interests without external constraints}

d14a3b7f-29f5-48ca-ad9d-a003375c8632.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-governance}, {Autonomy involves making choices based on one's own reasons}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can make decisions free from external coercion}

0bf4b5ef-9b1c-4cd4-8c0a-9426d9cd51fc.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable functionings}, {Capabilities are the real opportunities to accomplish what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the genuine ability to pursue their goals}

768ba353-4afb-4d85-8d97-33c4745efea3.content: {Freedom is the presence of control over one's own life}, {Positive liberty involves having the power and resources to fulfill one's potential}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the means to achieve their aspirations}

37b939b9-95bd-4073-b407-288cc9bde0e1.content: {There is a distinction between liberty and well-being}, {Freedom as non-interference is a theory about liberty, not about well-being}, {Maximizing liberty does not necessarily entail maximizing well-being}, {The objection confuses the concept of liberty with the concept of well-being}

70c3814d-8d3a-4d96-a52f-8c3af0994407.summary: Rejecting the assumption that liberty must lead to best outcomes
70c3814d-8d3a-4d96-a52f-8c3af0994407.content: {It is false that maximizing liberty must always lead to the best outcomes for individuals}, {The value of liberty is independent of the outcomes it produces}, {Individuals have the right to make choices, even if those choices lead to negative outcomes}

ae65ecc1-a978-438d-bf55-98cc46a309ce.summary: Supplementing with a principle of responsibility
ae65ecc1-a978-438d-bf55-98cc46a309ce.content: {Individuals are responsible for the consequences of their own choices}, {Maximizing liberty allows individuals to learn from their choices, including harmful or irrational ones}, {The objection loses its force when considering that personal growth and responsibility are part of the value of liberty}

0ad6d073-2334-47bb-9aed-976608817f97.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere with another's actions}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are protected from arbitrary interference by others}

17816d9b-2e8e-4804-b4f9-0089d0d1a4a4.content: {Freedom is the ability to pursue one's goals without unfair barriers}, {Unfair barriers include those created by unequal power dynamics}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have equal opportunities to pursue their goals}

1f624bea-a180-4569-8577-7340e8dc3670.content: {Freedom is the capacity to act according to one's own will}, {Empowerment involves having the resources and capabilities to make choices}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to make their own decisions}

39686a13-8f28-48fa-90ab-839134e3c32e.content: {Freedom is the absence of subjugation by others}, {Subjugation involves being subject to the will of another without consent}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are not subject to the will of others without their consent}

99a347ef-0785-4119-9d43-5783a5a792cf.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can make decisions independently of external control}

4e05c4ce-c4d1-43be-8d4a-a13f9a279194.content: {Freedom is the mutual recognition of individuals as equals}, {Recognition involves acknowledging the rights and dignity of others}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals recognize each other as equals with rights}

1d15394a-095a-41dc-aca1-f80f6d8595cc.content: {Freedom is the realization of social justice}, {Social justice involves the fair distribution of resources and opportunities}, {Liberty is maximized when society ensures fair distribution of resources and opportunities}

7f5d6d52-0ddd-49b6-bc89-08ec05624b51.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable outcomes}, {Capability involves having the means to pursue one's goals}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to achieve their desired outcomes}

7d6ce898-ad5d-42c8-827c-87a53259b745.content: {Freedom is the absence of exploitation by others}, {Exploitation involves taking unfair advantage of another's situation}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are protected from being exploited by others}

ff040add-99bf-46a1-a86b-0742ebb9bf43.content: {Freedom is the equality of power among individuals}, {Equality of power involves balancing power dynamics to prevent domination}, {Liberty is maximized when power is distributed equally to prevent domination}

4d27fe7e-e0fa-4dd3-bef9-039455a11f9c.content: {There is a distinction between interference and influence.}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with the absence of intentional prevention of actions, not with influence.}, {Unequal power dynamics may involve influence but do not necessarily involve interference.}, {Freedom can exist in a society with unequal power dynamics if there is no intentional prevention of actions.}

7070f40b-c47a-400b-8134-5ca269eb4486.summary: Rejecting the necessity of equal power for freedom
7070f40b-c47a-400b-8134-5ca269eb4486.content: {It is false that freedom requires equal power dynamics.}, {Freedom is defined by the absence of interference, not by the equality of power.}, {Unequal power dynamics do not inherently prevent individuals from acting without obstruction.}, {Liberty can be maximized even in the presence of unequal power, as long as there is no intentional prevention of actions.}

bc2ca2f8-ab0a-4f22-b9c9-614d8c572356.summary: Supplementing with a focus on legal and institutional safeguards
bc2ca2f8-ab0a-4f22-b9c9-614d8c572356.content: {Legal and institutional safeguards can prevent interference even in unequal power dynamics.}, {Freedom as non-interference can be maintained through laws that prevent intentional prevention of actions.}, {Institutions can ensure that individuals act without obstruction, regardless of power dynamics.}, {The presence of legal and institutional safeguards allows freedom to exist in a society with unequal power dynamics.}

c9506149-6498-473e-8d53-d6ce78a6e2e0.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from domination}

d077d258-1820-43b9-9a1d-e75ef6beb213.content: {Freedom is the ability to realize one's true self}, {Self-realization involves acting in accordance with one's rational will}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can pursue their own rational goals}

c8a24b3e-f766-4b72-ae29-e9c10119bf84.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-governance}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own reasons}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can make choices independently}

6a3843cd-9667-4e99-89e5-8752ee725791.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable functionings}, {Capabilities are the real opportunities to accomplish what one values}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to pursue their goals}

0dc045c1-afbf-4d53-a29c-98d57450e291.content: {Freedom is the empowerment to act effectively}, {Empowerment involves having the resources and opportunities to act}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to pursue their interests}

3a106601-9d48-4f54-bcdf-5c397ec128c4.summary: Distinguishing between personal and political freedom
3a106601-9d48-4f54-bcdf-5c397ec128c4.content: {There is a distinction between personal freedom and political freedom}, {Freedom as non-interference is a theory about personal freedom rather than political freedom}, {Political freedom may require additional elements like democratic participation, which are outside the scope of personal freedom as defined by non-interference}, {The absence of interference is sufficient for personal freedom, but political freedom may involve more complex conditions}

cf68fe6d-6fc4-4ccf-91c0-f7e0d47d69c5.summary: Rejecting the necessity of democratic participation for freedom
cf68fe6d-6fc4-4ccf-91c0-f7e0d47d69c5.content: {It is false that democratic participation is necessary for freedom}, {Freedom as non-interference focuses on the absence of intentional prevention of actions by others}, {Political freedom can be understood as a form of personal freedom where interference is minimized, regardless of the presence of democratic structures}, {The intuition that democratic participation is required for freedom is mistaken if freedom is defined solely as non-interference}

76ceb8bf-90a9-40c8-91f4-6b4e4286154f.summary: Supplementing with a distinction between negative and positive freedom
76ceb8bf-90a9-40c8-91f4-6b4e4286154f.content: {Negative freedom is defined as the absence of interference from others}, {Positive freedom involves the presence of conditions for self-realization, such as democratic participation}, {Freedom as non-interference addresses negative freedom, not positive freedom}, {The objection loses its force when recognizing that political freedom may require both negative and positive elements, but the theory only addresses the negative aspect}

6cf234e8-ce07-40f8-8ee6-6ea0dc2ce099.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from the threat of arbitrary interference}

94dc17ad-fd04-4b0c-b8d6-5aa3c53c482b.content: {Freedom is the availability of opportunities to act}, {Opportunities are determined by both resources and absence of interference}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the greatest range of opportunities to pursue their goals}

1ae05a0a-587b-4de9-8668-bfa8e98002fd.content: {Freedom is the capability to achieve desired outcomes}, {Capabilities are influenced by both personal abilities and external conditions}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capabilities to achieve their goals}

a13c9069-075b-45e9-8edb-4a8dfbc69ca2.content: {Freedom is the ability to determine one's own actions}, {Self-determination requires both autonomy and access to resources}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can autonomously pursue their chosen paths}

c4b7b84d-a7a0-4ec4-bddc-185723ee32ea.content: {Freedom is the empowerment to make meaningful choices}, {Empowerment involves both personal agency and supportive conditions}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to make choices that matter to them}

29b1a7f6-ca8f-4299-91a7-27c2c8335233.summary: Distinguishing between interference and resource limitation
29b1a7f6-ca8f-4299-91a7-27c2c8335233.content: {There is a distinction between interference by others and limitations due to resource scarcity}, {Freedom as non-interference is concerned with the absence of intentional prevention by others, not with resource availability}, {Resource scarcity does not constitute interference in the relevant sense of intentional prevention}, {Liberty can be maximized in terms of non-interference even if resources are limited}

462a30d6-697a-4ee0-bdff-23f9187332a7.summary: Rejecting the claim that resource scarcity inherently restricts liberty
462a30d6-697a-4ee0-bdff-23f9187332a7.content: {It is false that resource scarcity inherently restricts liberty in the sense of non-interference}, {Liberty as non-interference is about the absence of intentional obstruction, not about the availability of resources}, {The presence of limited resources does not equate to interference by others}

552501a5-1970-4574-8cd7-17e9277811d8.summary: Supplementing with a distinction between negative and positive liberty
552501a5-1970-4574-8cd7-17e9277811d8.content: {Negative liberty is defined as freedom from interference by others}, {Positive liberty involves having the means or resources to act}, {Freedom as non-interference is a theory of negative liberty, not positive liberty}, {Resource scarcity affects positive liberty but does not affect negative liberty as defined by non-interference}

92052210-f427-4a12-87ae-b1f0b732c052.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Domination involves the capacity to arbitrarily interfere}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are free from domination}

943891cf-a4ad-4179-af57-f1e39b3bbcea.content: {Freedom is the ability to achieve valuable functionings}, {Valuable functionings are states of being and doing that individuals have reason to value}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the capability to achieve these functionings}

d46f11e4-6a66-41dc-8df7-1f85ff929f6b.content: {Freedom is the empowerment to make meaningful choices}, {Empowerment involves having the resources and opportunities to choose}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals are empowered to make choices that affect their lives}

9d25eb85-f247-4269-bab0-c17da2263357.content: {Freedom is having a range of opportunities to choose from}, {Opportunities involve the availability of different courses of action}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have a wide range of opportunities}

cdd0ca00-9247-4031-bfdd-2ba56f70e345.content: {Freedom is the realization of one's true self}, {Self-realization involves achieving one's potential and personal goals}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can realize their true selves}

d2839a2b-11f5-4fd4-8332-0a5f3406b3ba.content: {Freedom is the capacity for autonomous decision-making}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasons}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can make autonomous decisions}

2f3b81ba-8c8a-43cb-b7c3-eabc9d058e55.content: {Freedom is the absence of constraints on action}, {Constraints involve both physical and social limitations}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals face minimal constraints}

83b55ff5-878e-4722-a374-5a34aed61b8b.content: {Freedom is the ability to determine one's own life course}, {Self-determination involves having control over one's personal and social environment}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can determine their own life course}

36cfb297-d55d-4b0a-b102-cab47c1e0ffc.content: {Freedom is the presence of conditions for self-mastery}, {Self-mastery involves control over one's desires and impulses}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals have the conditions for self-mastery}

e7b6f267-1a2e-4346-a28e-f0cb6eea1055.content: {Freedom is the development of human capacities}, {Development involves the growth of intellectual, emotional, and social abilities}, {Liberty is maximized when individuals can develop their capacities}

f80edc88-bf9b-481c-a723-a0f6db1b0e6c.summary: Distinguishing between negative and positive freedom
f80edc88-bf9b-481c-a723-a0f6db1b0e6c.content: {There is a distinction between negative freedom and positive freedom}, {Freedom as non-interference is a theory about negative freedom rather than positive freedom}, {Negative freedom involves the absence of interference, while positive freedom involves the presence of opportunities and capabilities}, {The focus on non-interference does not claim to address positive freedoms, which are a separate category}

35063dc7-e557-49c1-994f-14484cc93c5b.summary: Rejecting the necessity of positive freedoms for liberty
35063dc7-e557-49c1-994f-14484cc93c5b.content: {It is false that positive freedoms are necessary for liberty as defined by non-interference}, {Liberty is concerned with the absence of intentional prevention of actions by others}, {The ability to achieve one's potential or access opportunities is not required for liberty in the sense of non-interference}

eb414f93-cab8-4580-b5be-226b401e08be.summary: Supplementing with a framework for positive freedoms
eb414f93-cab8-4580-b5be-226b401e08be.content: {A supplementary framework can be adopted to address positive freedoms alongside non-interference}, {This framework can include measures to enhance opportunities and capabilities without altering the core concept of non-interference}, {The theory of freedom as non-interference remains intact while acknowledging the importance of positive freedoms in a broader context}

488ad4e8-ccb7-48d2-975a-f3d474e60a9f.content: {Freedom is the ability to determine one's own actions}, {Self-determination involves making choices that reflect one's authentic self}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act in accordance with their true self}

72b6e723-43a0-484f-9a7b-6f13b0da6206.content: {Freedom is the ability to reflect on and endorse one's own values}, {Reflective endorsement involves critically evaluating and accepting one's values as one's own}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals act according to values they have reflectively endorsed}

fb3b6537-a5dd-434c-9c0a-2ee02921ed12.content: {Freedom is the absence of domination by others}, {Non-domination involves being free from arbitrary interference by others}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals are not subject to the will of others}

6018514b-0999-49ce-9ed6-b8faafbd03a7.content: {Freedom is the ability to live authentically}, {Authenticity involves acting in accordance with one's true self and desires}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can express their true identity without external constraints}

8de82a01-5197-40ae-868b-738a054f16c2.content: {Freedom is the ability to realize one's potential}, {Self-realization involves developing and fulfilling one's capacities and talents}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can pursue their own growth and development}

769943d9-7a7d-44e6-84a5-61a7fe0d1549.content: {Freedom is the capacity to act as a rational agent}, {Rational agency involves making decisions based on reason and deliberation}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to rational deliberation}

0ad84a9e-81f3-4bb5-b692-e869586dbb44.content: {Freedom is the absence of coercion}, {Coercion involves being forced to act against one's will}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals are free from coercive influences}

531c644d-9aee-48e6-aaf6-0ed1592bb1f8.content: {Freedom is the ability to act according to moral principles}, {Moral autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own moral reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act in accordance with their moral convictions}

42f06d4a-87b6-4139-985d-79cd5f6ad132.content: {Freedom is the ability to maintain personal integrity}, {Personal integrity involves acting consistently with one's values and beliefs}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can live in a way that is true to their values}

e42cdf83-2804-4e19-bcbf-314412772826.content: {Freedom is the ownership of oneself}, {Self-ownership involves having control over one's own body and actions}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals have full control over their own lives}

6e2c3f94-7495-4cce-b98a-acbc726ad1c6.summary: Distinguishing between internal and external influences
6e2c3f94-7495-4cce-b98a-acbc726ad1c6.content: {There is a distinction between internal influences that are part of one's own reasoning and external influences that are imposed by others}, {Freedom as autonomy is concerned with internal influences rather than external ones}, {An individual can be autonomous if their decisions are based on internalized values, even if those values were initially shaped by external factors}, {The intuition that external shaping undermines freedom can be explained by confusing autonomy with independence from all external influences}

c9c2d83e-1ecc-40dc-9eea-e6dce575191e.summary: Rejecting the necessity of absence of external manipulation
c9c2d83e-1ecc-40dc-9eea-e6dce575191e.content: {It is false that freedom requires the complete absence of external manipulation}, {Autonomy can exist even if one's values and reasoning have been influenced by external factors, as long as the individual endorses those values upon reflection}, {The presence of external influences does not necessarily negate the ability to govern oneself if the individual identifies with the influenced values}

d305cd84-81d2-4685-9f63-92705233ca3f.content: {Autonomy involves the capacity for reflective endorsement, meaning the ability to reflect on and endorse one's values and reasoning}, {Even if values are shaped by external influences, autonomy is achieved if the individual reflectively endorses those values}, {The appearance of lacking freedom due to external shaping is addressed by focusing on the individual's capacity for reflection and endorsement}

d7c33dea-3cbf-4603-8bca-2ca6d62dc023.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values that one has reflectively endorsed}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

92fe2991-8f98-434a-9f3f-24b1f8a60665.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values that are authentic to the individual}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

86c04a70-db5f-4383-a6f6-01521805f928.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values that have been critically reflected upon}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

c00b92ab-05a4-4b43-a0e4-131aa7099a37.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on a coherent set of values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

3cdfa7c1-af42-486d-9b4a-ea6e4f8dccf5.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values that one has determined for oneself}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

9d79e103-e404-4bcf-8f3c-405157884422.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that maintain personal integrity}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

06727c43-1df8-4be6-8906-5d77f4a1f7b5.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on rational deliberation of one's values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

3b8802dd-264b-4154-81ef-578f49fdb335.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values that one genuinely owns}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

51592305-8e08-4546-9b4b-71d47b84ff29.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions as the author of one's own values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

8a0798dc-8c88-43c9-a7b8-8e0f6ef951ca.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on well-informed values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}

63b63498-d67c-4f98-9204-afd90f890b5f.summary: Distinguishing between internal and external value formation
63b63498-d67c-4f98-9204-afd90f890b5f.content: {There is a distinction between values formed internally and those imposed externally}, {Freedom as autonomy concerns values that are formed internally through personal reflection and reasoning}, {Values instilled through coercion are not considered genuinely one's own in the context of autonomy}, {A person is not autonomous if their values are imposed externally, even if they act according to those values}

39403fae-d899-40f6-be69-e4fa0e6bf969.summary: Rejecting the necessity of original value ownership
39403fae-d899-40f6-be69-e4fa0e6bf969.content: {It is false that autonomy requires values to be originally one's own}, {Autonomy can be achieved if a person critically reflects on and endorses their values, regardless of their origin}, {The process of reflection and endorsement is what grants autonomy, not the initial source of the values}

295eeae9-df0a-4cc8-b432-b595348683e3.summary: Supplementing with the concept of reflective endorsement
295eeae9-df0a-4cc8-b432-b595348683e3.content: {Reflective endorsement is the process of critically evaluating and accepting one's values}, {Autonomy requires that individuals reflectively endorse their values, not that the values originate internally}, {A person can be autonomous if they have reflectively endorsed values, even if those values were initially instilled through coercion}

c693d939-702b-4805-aabf-e654014712c0.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will without coercion}

f9560784-1b15-4c55-9be5-215e09926d10.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own authentic values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own authentic will}

3309b7a9-0901-44c6-a9c1-02ab1af7c6cb.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on values and reasoning that one reflectively endorses}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their reflectively endorsed will}

3ff85a0c-d1ba-437a-a83d-e4160d4a6e60.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will without being dominated by others}

aa5d918a-cbca-4526-9c78-2eb71e2e970a.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on rational values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their rational will}

d5f5bb07-6489-4556-bae3-f5673f5b3fb4.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on well-informed values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their well-informed will}

f5c99994-b0c1-4938-8a67-b03773460c8d.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on a coherent set of values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their coherent will}

6408612a-fd11-4b3b-98df-6e917ffc189b.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions through a fair and unbiased process of reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their procedurally fair will}

8ac53f0a-f4f4-43fa-a3ce-02c56b141640.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will without interference from others}

5e7535a0-ea34-4d0f-ae5f-47b732a33104.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that lead to self-realization}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their self-realizing will}

c21cce10-b156-4b4d-a4b1-a93b4fc67dd7.summary: Distinguishing between internal and external coercion
c21cce10-b156-4b4d-a4b1-a93b4fc67dd7.content: {There is a distinction between internal coercion and external coercion}, {Freedom as autonomy is concerned with the absence of external coercion rather than internal coercion}, {An individual who adopts desires due to internal coercion is still acting according to their own will in the relevant sense}, {The intuition that coerced desires undermine liberty can be explained by confusion between internal and external coercion}

c95c8806-3f8d-47c3-b535-4d4dfd3d45ab.summary: Rejecting the necessity of coercion absence for liberty
c95c8806-3f8d-47c3-b535-4d4dfd3d45ab.content: {It is false that liberty requires the complete absence of coercion}, {Liberty as autonomy focuses on the ability to act according to one's own values and reasoning, even if those values were initially influenced by coercion}, {The presence of coercion does not necessarily negate the capacity for self-governance if the individual can still make decisions based on their own reasoning}

0130f613-5531-4e0c-a1dd-de7f682a8070.summary: Supplementing with the concept of reflective endorsement
0130f613-5531-4e0c-a1dd-de7f682a8070.content: {Reflective endorsement involves critically evaluating and accepting one's desires and values}, {Freedom as autonomy can include the capacity for reflective endorsement of one's desires}, {An individual who reflectively endorses their coerced desires can still be considered autonomous}, {The appearance of lacking liberty due to coercion is mitigated if the individual has reflectively endorsed their desires}

8380ed40-cf69-44b2-b06b-d9b7e3f8ef0b.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that one reflectively endorses}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their reflectively endorsed values}

fb7007f8-55d1-4862-9cce-a3f5ed1dd50e.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on informed values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their informed will}

e403e557-cf0d-44bb-b1ba-2640106539d6.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions through rational deliberation}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their rationally deliberated choices}

ac36570d-6335-4df6-bc5c-76c3a36f632d.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that are coherent with one's values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act in a manner coherent with their values}

9b8ef4a1-fea1-4cc2-b7aa-6f9f1df04503.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions after critical reflection on one's values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to critically reflected values}

614d45d5-6fac-4286-8bf0-580256b332c6.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions with an understanding of one's own motivations}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act with self-understanding}

1ed1c46c-8007-4b14-9b30-08ca2288e990.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that are authentic to one's true self}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act authentically}

db16d092-77fe-4a4d-816a-5f618b60f797.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that determine one's own path}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act in self-determined ways}

3a5342a1-e8b1-4944-a3a4-6e35c790145a.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions aligned with one's core values}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act in alignment with their core values}

4ec3d2ef-39e1-4961-a746-741d8761711b.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions that express one's individuality}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act as an expression of their individuality}

a28e31dd-01dd-4e98-98bc-aef6a46e8974.content: {There is a distinction between autonomy and complete self-awareness}, {Freedom as autonomy is a theory about self-governance rather than self-awareness}, {A person can be autonomous even if they are not fully aware of all their subconscious biases}, {Autonomy involves acting according to one's values and reasoning, which can occur without complete self-awareness}

a091602c-e0e7-4c74-89f3-7952fd4372f8.summary: Rejecting the necessity of complete self-awareness for autonomy
a091602c-e0e7-4c74-89f3-7952fd4372f8.content: {It is false that complete self-awareness is necessary for autonomy}, {Autonomy is primarily about the ability to act according to one's own values and reasoning}, {Subconscious biases do not necessarily undermine the capacity for self-governance}

fb579faa-039a-4965-8e57-8f808a0df875.content: {Autonomy can be supplemented by the concept of reflective endorsement}, {Reflective endorsement involves critically evaluating and endorsing one's values and decisions}, {A person can be autonomous if they have the capacity for reflective endorsement, even if they are not fully aware of all subconscious biases}

f78dddaa-897d-496e-a65b-7ab023e94a10.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}, {Freedom is compatible with determinism if one's actions align with their values and reasoning}

7257ee51-b0f5-4877-b6e4-3a575a555376.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}, {Freedom is achieved when higher-order desires align with first-order actions}

d044b0c3-19a3-43f5-8752-4f94a8b5f052.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}, {Freedom requires the capacity to respond to reasons, even in a deterministic framework}

b1a20156-d670-4ffd-a350-eb439753490e.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}, {Freedom is the result of being the source of one's actions, regardless of determinism}

455d172d-c293-427c-8b42-603179b676ac.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself}, {Autonomy involves making decisions based on one's own values and reasoning}, {Liberty is achieved when individuals can act according to their own will}, {Freedom is present when one's actions are coherent with their values and beliefs, even if determined}

d62de809-4bd4-480f-ba12-8e5936d4c1ee.summary: Distinguishing between autonomy and alternative possibilities
d62de809-4bd4-480f-ba12-8e5936d4c1ee.content: {There is a distinction between autonomy and the ability to do otherwise}, {Freedom as autonomy focuses on self-governance rather than the availability of alternative possibilities}, {An individual can be autonomous even if their actions are determined, as long as they act according to their own values and reasoning}, {The intuition that freedom requires the ability to do otherwise can be explained as a confusion between autonomy and alternative possibilities}
